clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Compare CAUTI Rates Following ERASE CAUTI Tray Silver vs Silver Coated Foley Catheters
clinical_study.official_title: A Clinical Study to Compare the CAUTI Rates Following ERASE CAUTI Tray Silver Coated Foley Catheters Verse Silver Coated Foley Catheters

brief_summary.textblock: The Foley catheter is one component in a catheter insertion procedure that could contribute to a catheter associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI). Improvements in the catheter insertion procedure using the ERASE CAUTI Tray system may help to lower these infection rates.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 days on average or until hospital discharge
primary_outcome.description: Infection rate/1000 catheter days based on days of use. As the number of days a catheter is used varies, the minimum expected time frame on average is 2 days. However, infections will be monitored during catheter use.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2 days on average or until hospital discharge
secondary_outcome.description: The average number of days a catheter is used is typically 2 days. However during the hospital stay, the time a catheter remains varies on medical need. The total daily use of each catheter will be tabulated after removal..

secondary_outcome.measure: Catheter Associated Urinary Track Infection Costs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post Infection costs incurred from insertion of catheter to hospital discharge (<30 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Costs associated with urinary track Infections during the use of a catheter in the study will calculated from the time infection was identified until hospital discharge.

arm_group.description: Subjects given silver catheters from an ERASE CAUTI Tray.

intervention.description: Foley catheter from ERASE CAUTI Kit will be administered as required.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 18 years of age
- Received either silver coated Foley catheter or ERASE CAUTI silver coated catheter
Exclusion Criteria:
- UTI present upon current hospital admission
- Burn patients, transplant patients, or immune-compromised patients.
